screeningSummary: Air traffic controller with three official incident reports about radar-confirmed object with vertical acceleration

textVariants.text: You're on the air. You said you have professional experience in aviation?
textVariants.voiceText: You're on the air. You said you have professional experience in aviation?

textVariants.text: Alright, you're on. You said you fly or something?
YOU ARE ON THE AIR! Aviation experience, huh?! This is gonna be good!
You're on. Look, I've heard a lot tonight - what makes yours different?
You're on. So you work in aviation? What about it?
Oh, an aviation person! This I gotta hear. What's your story?
You're on the air. What's your background in aviation?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Air traffic controller for fifteen years, Vern. I've tracked something that to this day I cannot explain, and I've filed three official incident reports about it.

textVariants.text: Three incident reports. That's serious. Tell me what you saw.
Three reports, huh? Alright, I'll listen... what's the gist?
THREE incident reports?! This is HUGE! Every detail, don't leave anything out!
Three reports? You don't say. Let me guess... aliens, right?
Three reports. Fine, I'll bite. What'd you see?
Three official reports! This is fantastic - I've been waiting for a case like this!
Three incident reports with documentation. That's a paper trail I can work with. Walk me through the timeline.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: November 14th, 2:47 AM. Object appeared on primary radar at 40,000 feet, descending. No transponder, no flight plan, nothing in the system. It descended to 100 feet in four seconds.

textVariants.text: Four seconds. That rate of descent would destroy conventional aircraft.
Four seconds... yeah, that'd wreck most planes. So what happened next?
FOUR SECONDS from 40,000 feet?! That's impossible for any known aircraft!
Four seconds. Of course it did. Let me guess - it hovered, right?
Four seconds. That's fast. Most planes couldn't handle that. Go on.
FOUR SECONDS! The physics don't work for any normal aircraft! This is exactly why I do this show!
40,000 to 100 feet in four seconds. That's a 12,000 foot per minute descent rate. Impossible for conventional aircraft. What happened after the descent?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Correct. Then it hovered over the water for six minutes. Multiple controllers witnessed it. I called Coast Guard dispatch. Their boat was twelve miles out. The crew saw it visually before it accelerated straight up and vanished.

textVariants.text: Six minutes hovering, multiple witnesses, Coast Guard confirmation. That's multiple independent confirmations.
Six minutes... Coast Guard saw it too. Alright, that's more than one person.
SIX MINUTES of hovering with Coast Guard visual confirmation?! This is TEXTBOOK material right here!
Of course it hovered for six minutes. What'd it do at the end?
Six minutes, multiple witnesses, Coast Guard confirmation. That's not nothing.
This is EXACTLY why I love this show! Multiple controllers, Coast Guard visual, six minutes of hovering - this is as real as it gets!
Six minutes stationary over water, multiple radar confirmations, then vertical acceleration. That trajectory data is critical. What was the final heading before it vanished?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: We considered every explanation. Multiple independent radar systems, visual confirmation from a Coast Guard vessel - that's not electronic warfare, Vern. That's something else entirely. The official report was classified, but we know what we saw.

textVariants.text: Thank you for your testimony. Multiple independent confirmations make this exactly the kind of credible account that needs to be heard. We'll keep asking those questions.
Yeah, someone should look into this. Thanks for calling in. We'll... we'll figure this out.
We're going to get ANSWERS! This is exactly why this show exists - to give people like you a platform! We're just getting started on this story!
Right, well... someone should be asking questions. I guess that's us then. Thanks for calling.
Someone should be asking questions. That's what we're here for. Thanks for coming forward with this.
This made you question everything you thought you knew? That's exactly why I do this show! Now thousands of people heard your story. Thank you!
The highest levels need to see this data. Multiple radar returns, visual confirmation, official reports - this creates a pattern that can't be ignored. Your testimony is documented. Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Someone should be asking questions at the highest level. I appreciate you giving me the platform, Vern. This is bigger than any one of us.

arcNotes: Air traffic controller, multiple radar confirmations, Coast Guard visual, classified report, extremely credible
